metadata.title: Interstitial Cystitis (Painful Bladder Syndrome)
description: The International Continence Society defines interstitial cystitis (IC), also known as painful bladder syndrome, as a clinical syndrome consisting of suprapubic pain related to bladder filling and accompanied by other symptoms such as increased daytime and nighttime urinary frequency in the absence of proven infection or other obvious pathology.(1) The American Urological Association (AUA) defines IC as an unpleasant sensation perceived to be related to the bladder that is associated with lower urinary tract symptoms > 6 weeks’ duration, in the absence of infection or other unidentifiable causes.(1) The Canadian Urological Association (CUA) uses the same definition as the AUA in their guidelines(12)
reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified. Health insurance benefits for physical therapy for IC vary
presentation signs and symptoms: Most common symptoms(6) –Suprapubic pain with bladder filling that is relieved with urination –Urgency, frequency (> 8 times during the day) and nocturia (> 2 times at night)
Anterior vaginal wall/bladder neck pain in females
Intensity of symptoms waxes and wanes with symptoms lasting > 6 months
Insidious onset; worsens to final level in 5 to 15 years
Most common in the 4th and 5th decades of life but may occur at any age
Females > males 10:1(2) –White females constitute 95% of patients with IC(1)
Incidence: 21 cases per 100,000 women and 4 cases per 100,000 men annually(1)

Prevalence –197 per 100,000 women and 41 per 100,000 men in the United States; however, IC is greatly underdiagnosed and may actually affect 1 in 5 women and 1 in 20 men(1)  Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Only clinicians specifically trained in the evaluation/treatment of pelvic floor dysfunction should carry out portions of the examination related to this region
Prior to initiating an assessment of the pelvic floor, the clinician must receive orders from the physician and informed consent from the patient
Maneuvers that duplicate the patient’s pain should be noted, but undue reproduction of pain should be avoided to minimize guarding, which can interfere with performance of a thorough exam

pathogenesis: IC is thought to be a spectrum of multiple forms of chronic pelvic pain(13)
Damage to the glycosaminoglycan mucus layer may increase bladder wall permeability to irritants such as urea(2)

Other possible factors(2)–Autoimmune response–Mast cell histamine release–Neurologic upregulation/stimulation-A process by which sensitivity to neurotransmitters or hormones is increased, often due to an increase in the number ofreceptors in the target cells-Neurologic upregulation can cause hyperalgesia and allodynia in end organs other than those in which a painfulcondition exists
risk factors: History of urinary tract infections (UTIs) and bladder problems in childhood(6)

overall contraindications precautions: Patients may be very frustrated. Symptoms may be debilitating but are not evident to others

Always respect the patient’s pain level. The Interstitial Cystitis Guidelines Panel of the AUA and the CUA recommend that pain management be continually assessed because of its importance to quality of life. If pain management is inadequate, consideration should be given to a multidisciplinary team approach and appropriate referrals should be made(13)
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Etiology usually is difficult to determine.(13)Does patient have a history of pelvic pain and urgency/frequency? Does patient report frequent UTIs, vaginitis, or symptoms in the week before menses? Does the patient have a history of pelvic surgery or radiation therapy? Any history of incontinence? When did symptoms begin? Have they progressed? When was diagnosis made?

course of treatment.medical management: What medical treatment has the patient received, if any? On average, patients see 5 different physicians and endure IC symptoms for 5 years before IC is properly identified(1) There is no consensus on optimal management for this condition, and no cure(1) Treatment may include advice to avoid activities associated with flare-ups,  dietary restrictions, exercise, behavioral therapy, bladder retraining, biofeedback, warm sitz baths, and massage(1)  Surgery and other procedures are not typically performed unless more conservative approaches have not provided acceptable symptom control and quality of life is significantly affected(1) Sacral neuromodulation is the current preferred surgical intervention(1) Hydraulic distention of bladder under anesthesia may provide transient symptomatic relief(2) Superior hypogastric plexus neurolysis may be used to relieve chronic pelvic pain but also lacks durability in cases of IC. Multimodal treatment often is needed to control patients’ symptoms(10) Laser ablation, fulguration, or resection to treat Hunner’s ulcers(1) Augmentation cystoplasty is performed to increase bladder capacity and decrease pressure, with or without partial cystectomy (bladder removal). It is generally not recommended(1) Partial cystectomy in severe cases, total cystectomy if completely refractory to medical therapy(2) Urinary diversion with total cystectomy only if disease is completely refractory to medical therapy(2)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? What effect do they have on the symptoms? Most medications for IC demonstrate limited benefit over placebo in RCTs(2) Oral medication is tried first.(1) Most treatments take 3 to 6 months before maximum benefit is observed.(1) Adjunct oral therapy includes amitriptyline, cimetidine, hydroxyzine, oral pentosan polysulfate, intravesical pentosan polysulfate, cyclosporine A, gabapentin, quercetin, pyridium, hyoscine butylbromide, vaginal valium suppository, vaginal baclofen, belladonna and opiate suppository(13) Pentosanpolysulfate sodium is the only oral medication approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for treating IC(1) Amitriptyline is often prescribed to relieve pain and urinary frequency(6) Hydroxyzine pamoate causes sedation and helps reduce urinary frequency(6) Long-term  antibiotics should never be administered and are contraindicated in patients who have previously been administered antibiotics without efficacy and who present with a negative urine culture(4) Long-term  systemic oral glucocorticosteroids should not be offered.(4) Oral prednisone is used in the presence of Hunner’s ulcers(1) Intravesical treatment is used when oral medications fail, for acute flare-ups,  or before the oral medications take full effect. Instilled medications are injected directly into the bladder. This typically involves a mixture of heparin or pentosan polysulfate sodium, with lidocaine and sodium bicarbonate.(1) Lidocaine, heparin, and dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) may be administered in this manner(1) DMSO is the only FDA-approved  intravesical treatment; however, it is used less often now because of its side effects, specifically a garliclike  odor or taste on breath or skin that lasts 72 hours after treatment(1) Intravesical instillation of bacillus Calmette-Guerin  should not be offered outside of investigational study settings. Intravesical instillation of resiniferatoxin should not be offered(4) Some patients may try an OTC food additive known as Prelief for symptom control(1)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed: There is no definitive diagnostic test. IC is a diagnosis of exclusion when no known cause of painful bladder can be identified.(1) In up to 40% of patients referred to a urologist for suspected IC, another medical condition ultimately is diagnosed.(6)Tests for this condition may include the following:
Urinalysis and culture; should be negative in cases of IC(6)
Urine cytology if hematuria is present; should be negative in cases of IC(6)
CT or ultrasound of abdomen and pelvis to rule out other pathology(1)
Urodynamic testing to assess bladder sensation and compliance and exclude detrusor instability
Cystoscopy and biopsy may be performed
Presence of submucosal mast cells is not needed to make the diagnosis of IC(6)
Biopsy used to rule out carcinoma, eosinophilic cystitis, and tuberculous cystitis(6)
The CUA guidelines make the following suggestions, including grades and levels of evidence:(12)
Ultrasound/pelvic imaging (optional, select patients, grade C, level 4 evidence)
Frequency volume chart (recommended all patients, grade C, level 3 evidence) +/- post-void residual (optional, when indicated, grade C, level 4 evidence)
Laboratory tests: Urinalysis, culture (recommended all patients, grade C, level 4 evidence), cytology (optional, when indicated, grade C, level 4 evidence)
Cystoscopy (recommended, all patients, grade C, level 3 evidence)
Intravesical anesthetic bladder challenge (optional, select patients, grade C, level 3 evidence)
Hydrodistension (optional, select patients, grade C, level 3 evidence)
Urodynamics (UDS) (not recommended in the routine evaluation of IC/bladder pain syndrome (BPS), grade C, level 3 evidence)
Bladder biopsy (not recommended in the routine evaluation of IC/BPS, grade C, level 3 evidence)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or complementary therapies (e.g., acupuncture, herbal supplements) and whether they help Patients may try relaxation and stress reduction techniques such as meditation tapes, visualization, guided imagery, selfhypnosis, massage, or psychotherapy Patients may try herbal remedies such as Algonot Plus, CystoProtek, Cysta-Q,  and aloe vera(1)
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors -Emotional or physical stress is often reported to exacerbate symptoms(13) -Consumption of specific foods may increase symptoms; citrus, coffee, alcohol, carbonated drinks, tomatoes, and chocolate are common irritants(12) -Pain only with voiding does not indicate IC but a vulvar disorder(12) -Symptoms typically are worse when the bladder is filled and relieved after emptying,(1)which is in contrast to overactive bladder, in which patients void for fear of incontinence(12) -Symptoms are often worse before menses, in contrast to endometriosis,in which symptoms are worse during menses(12)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms -Initially patients will report pressure or burning in suprapubic area, but pain can be referred to the urethra, vagina, labia, inguinal area, perineum, and/or lower abdomen or back(12)
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Intensity of symptoms typically waxes and wanes -Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables -The patient may be asked to keep a voiding diary to document symptoms. The voiding diary of a patient with IC tends to show a pattern of low-volume, high-frequency  voiding
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night -Nocturia is common and tends to increase as the severity of IC increases -Sleep deprivation may be a problem(9)Document any need for supplemental oxygen or the need for ventilation
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Note any history of respiratory problems Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Does patient have a history of recurrent UTIs, urgency, or pelvic pain that may have been diagnosed as something else? More than 81% of women in whom chronic pelvic pain is diagnosed and up to 84% of men in whom chronic prostatitis initially is diagnosed actually have IC(1) In patients with a diagnosis of overactive bladder who do not respond to anticholinergics, IC often is later diagnosed
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems. IC is often associated with irritable bowel syndrome, migraines, endometriosis, skin sensitivities, allergies, vulvodynia, fibromyalgia, chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS), systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), and mood disorders(1) Vesicoureteral reflux is a complication of IC that is not uncommon, and is associated with periureterally located Hunner lesions.(11) Hunner ulcers are a typical diagnostic finding in patients with IC and are defined as any welldemarcated  erythematous mucosal lesions that produce bleeding and pain when touched with a cystoscope(11)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs). Even common OTC supplements have the potential to act as irritants and should be noted
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does patient work? Do the symptoms interfere with patient’s ability to complete required tasks? Does the patient participate in any recreational activities, and if so, do the symptoms interfere with participation?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Does the patient have any functional limitations? Frequent urination and pain may interfere with social activities. Dyspareunia may interfere with personal relationships
social and occupational history.living environment: Ask about access to bathroom facilities. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Measure height and weight; calculate BMI; check leg length for asymmetryComplete a general balance and gait assessment
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess strength of the hips, trunk (abdominal and back extensors), and pelvic floor muscles –Identify any areas of weakness or imbalance –Also note musculature that may be tight or in spasm –Document the presence and location of pain upon manual muscle testing (MMT)
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess the pelvis for rotation, tilt –Check for iliac crest height symmetry –Assess for postural variations such as increased lordosis or kyphosis, or knee hyperextension –Assess weight-bearing  distribution in sitting and standing
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Determine active and passive ROM and flexibility of the hips and trunk –Measure trunk flexion, extension, rotation, and side bending and note any reproduction of pain or protective muscle guarding  –Test for flexibility of hamstrings, iliotibial bands, quadriceps, piriformis, and hip flexors and rotators as indicated
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assess lower extremity reflexes bilaterallyUse a standardized self-report  questionnaire as indicated
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Complete a dermatome scan to assess for neurological involvement if indicated
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis(12) -Interstitial Cystitis Symptom Index (ICSI) -Interstitial Cystitis Problem Index (ICPI) -The ICSI and ICPI have been combined (O’Leary-Sant  Symptom and Problem Index);at the O’Leary-Sant  measures urgency, frequency, nocturia, and pain over the past month, and has been shown to have good reliability and validity -The Wisconsin Interstitial Cystitis Scale (UW-IC Scale) -Validated and comprehensive but not well-adopted  in clinical practice -Pain, Urgency, Frequency score (PUF score) -Includes measures for pelvic pain and dyspareunia; has not been as validated as others -Bladder Pain/IC Symptom Score (BPIC-SS) -Used to determine qualification for clinical trials –Experienced women’s health physical therapists should complete a thorough pelvic examination (e.g., intravaginal examination assessing for muscle spasm in the pelvic floor)

contraindications precautions: Over the trunk or heart region in patients with demand-type pacemakers and implantable cardioverter defibrillators (ICDs)
Over the pelvic, abdominal, lumbar, or hip region of a pregnant woman
Over the phrenic nerve, eyes, or gonads
Over areas of known peripheral vascular disease
With patients with compromised mental ability
With cardiac dysfunction (uncontrolled hypertension or hypotension, irregular heartbeat)
With electrodes -Over compromised skin, unless treating wound specifically -Over tissues that are vulnerable to hemorrhage -Cervical region in patients with history of stroke or seizures
Do not use within 5 yards of diathermy units or other source of electromagnetic radiation
Over an area of peripheral vascular disease
Over an area of poor sensation
In the very young or very old
Over areas with a lack of intact thermal sensation
Over areas of vascular insufficiency or vascular disease
Over areas of recent hemorrhage or potential hemorrhage
Over infected areas where infection may spread
Over areas where liniments or heat rubs have recently been applied
In any situation deemed unreliable by the practitioner
other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols
Pelvic-floor  strengthening exercises (e.g., Kegel exercises) should be avoided(4) until pelvic floor muscle spasm has resolved

Electrotherapy  contraindications (in some cases, when approved by the treating physician, electrotherapy may be used under some of the circumstances listed below when benefits outweigh the perceived risk)(5)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Symptoms of suprapubic pain and urinary frequency and urgency for greater than 6 months accompanied by pelvic floor tightness and/or tenderness, abdominal tenderness, and functional limitations Rule out  (1,6) Chronic pelvic pain Chronic prostatitisgenital herpes Bacterial cystitis Overactive bladder Recurrent UTI Vaginitis Endometriosis Pelvic adhesions Vulvar vestibulitis Vulvodynia Urethral diverticulum Urethral carcinoma Radiation cystitis Chemical-induced  cystitis (cyclophosphamide)
prognosis: There is no cure for IC. Results vary per individual, but most patients gain symptomatic relief.(6)No single treatment has been found effective for the majority of patients; acceptable symptom control may require trials of multiple treatment options before symptom control is achieved(4)

Approximately 20% to 30% of patients notice symptomatic improvements following hydrodistention (over-filling  the bladder with fluid while under general anesthesia);(6) however, it typically provides only temporary relief and is no longer commonly performed(1)
Up to 50% of patients have a spontaneous remission of symptoms after a mean duration of 8 months without treatment(6)
If case is mild, patient usually experiences exacerbations and remissions of symptoms. May not be progressive and does not predispose to other diseases(2)
If severe, patient experiences progressive problems that usually require surgery to control symptoms. Long-term continuous high bladder pressure can be associated with renal damage(2)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Urologist, pain specialist, psychologist for stress management and relaxation, support groups
other considerations: Sacral nerve stimulation (SNS), also called neuromodulation, has been approved by the FDA for treatment of patients with intractable urge urinary incontinence, refractory urgency-frequency  syndrome, and voiding difficulty; it has not been approved for IC in Canada(12) –SNS is applied by a neurostimulator that is implanted in the patient's lower abdomen. SNS is generally first tried on an outpatient basis in the doctor's office with the implantation of a test lead. If trial treatment is successful, the patient is scheduled for inpatient surgery –The CUA recommends SNS only as an option for the treatment of IC in patients who have symptoms refractory to multiple other treatments(12)

Intradetrusor botulinum toxin type A (BTX-A)  injections may be administered if other treatments have not provided adequate symptom control and quality of life is impaired. Patients must understand that post treatment intermittent self-catheterization  may be necessary.(4)BTX-A  is not effective in the treatment of ulcer type IC(2)
Emerging therapies for IC include hyperbaric oxygen, phosphodiesterase-5  (PDE-5)  inhibitors, and monoclonal antibodies against TNF-alpha(12)
treatment summary: The best treatment for IC should be individualized and address the patient’s unique clinical phenotype(12)

The 2016 CUA guidelines suggest the following conservative treatments, including grade of evidence:(12) –Patient education (recommended in all patients, grade A) and dietary modifications (recommended in all patients, grade B) –Bladder training (recommended in motivated patients, grade B) –Stress-management  techniques, psychological support (recommended in patients experiencing stress or psychological dysfunction, grade B) –Physiotherapy and massage (recommended for patients with pelvic floor dysfunction, grade A) – focus is on treatment that promotes relaxation, and elongates, stretches, and massages tightened muscles –Acupuncture (option in motivated patients, grade B) –Trigger-point  injections (option for patients with trigger-point  pain, grade D)

The Interstitial Cystitis Guidelines Panel of the AUA conducted a systematic review of the literature published through 2009. The panel lists manual physical therapy techniques by appropriately trained clinicians as a second-line  treatment for IC.(4) First-line treatments include patient education, self-care  practices and behavior modification, and stress-management practices to manage stress-induced  symptom exacerbations.(4) Maneuvers that resolve pelvic, abdominal, and/or hip muscular trigger points, lengthen muscle contractures, and release painful scars and other connective tissue restrictions should be offered.(4)Pelvic-floor  strengthening exercises (e.g., Kegel exercises) should be avoided(4)

Myofascial physical therapy has been reported to have potential benefit for women with IC(3) –Authors of a U.S. multicenter RCT compared pelvic floor myofascial physical therapy to global therapeutic massage(3) -Eighty-one  women with similar symptoms at baseline, of less than 3 years’ duration, were randomized to the 2 treatment groups -Participants had demonstrable pelvic-floor  tenderness on physical examination -Primary outcome was response on a 7-point  global assessment scale. Secondary outcomes included pain, urgency, and frequency -Myofascial physical therapy consisted of targeted internal and external tissue manipulation, focusing on the muscles and connective tissue of the pelvic floor, hip girdle, and abdomen. Global therapeutic massage was a full-body-massage program -Nearly 60% of the women receiving myofascial physical therapy experienced moderate or marked improvement in overall symptoms, compared to only 26% of the global therapeutic massage group  -Lack of follow-up  prevented any conclusions about the durability of the response to this therapy beyond the 12-week treatment program –Authors of a narrative review of physical therapy interventions in IC came to the following conclusions:(14) -Physiotherapy can improve patient care through bladder training techniques along with stress reduction methods. In addition, certain types of manual techniques, when administered by an experienced physiotherapist, may alleviate symptoms –Use of modalities for pain (local heat, cold packs, TENS), biofeedback bladder retraining,(2) and guided imagery(2) have been reported to help alleviate symptoms of IC. Gentle exercises such as low-impact  aerobics, walking, yoga, and swimming may be useful in reducing symptoms(1) –There is a void in the literature of RCTs on the effectiveness of therapy for IC(8) -In a U.S. study, 1,982 subjects with IC completed a survey on the use of complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) therapies -84.2% reported trying diet or physical therapy; 69.2% reported trying other therapies. Of 49 possible CAM therapies, 22 were rated as having a positive effect, 20 were rated as having a negative effect, and 7 were rated as inconclusive -Therapies perceived as helpful were dietary management, pain management, physical therapy, stress reduction, acupuncture, exercise, sleep hygiene, heat, cold, meditation, and relaxation -Subjects with acute cases reported better effects of therapies compared to those with a chronic history of IC . maintenance or prevention: Early identification and intervention results in better patient outcomes

Some patients achieve symptom alleviation by eliminating certain foods and beverages from their diets. Eliminate one item at a time to see if symptoms abate. Avoid common irritants, including caffeine, chocolate, citrus, tomatoes, carbonated beverages, potassium-rich  food, spicy foods, acidic foods, and alcohol(1,2) The Interstitial Cystitis Association lists the following foods and beverages as some of the possible causes of bladder irritation: cheese; alcohol; artificial sweeteners; processed meats; most fruits (e.g., grapefruit, oranges, pineapple); pickles; soy; tea; tomatoes; and yogurt(7)
Empowering patients to manage their symptoms and learn as much as possible about this condition may help improve outcomes(2)
Encourage patients to implement stress-management  practices to improve coping techniques and manage stress-induced exacerbations(4)
For women of childbearing years, symptoms are unpredictable and can improve or be exacerbated by pregnancy(2)
